title: "Boards just rant we don't have any suggestions"
body:
I've never understood this.

People complain that the board just rants about what's wrong with League, but they don't offer suggestions on how to fix it. Now, if the average League player is like me, we may feel or know something is wrong but we don't know how to fix it.

### We don't develop games.

We're essentially customers of this service, which is League of Legends. If this were a normal product such as let's say food.

Let's assume we were regular individuals who did not know how to cook and we bit into a piece of chicken our mom's made. We find the chicken is too salty, we state this fact. Why should simply stating this fact be a problem? It lets the person who cooked the chicken, in this case created the game, knows that were is a problem with their product/service.
While we have not offered any advice on how to make the chicken taste any less salty, as we cannot cook (develop games/code/balance champions) as we have never learnt how. (It's not our area of expertise to balance/design champions)

**And if you're like me who plays League but isn't one of those mathematicians you see on the boards going, well his Q does X and True damage is equals to Z, so you X*Z=Y/C...those guys** we won't be of any real help in stats.

The average player just knows when there is a problem, can feel when there is a problem or see when there is a problem. Just because we don't know how to fix it, does not mean our opinion on the game should be ignored.

Mindblown.gif
It's almost as if every complaint on the boards is about the high damage in this game being a problem...wait a minute.

statistics do not give the whole story.  If one player compared to 100 can achieve a perfect 100% win rate when everyone else has 50% , the average is 50.5% while it would be very rare to see this player, does that mean that there is not a problem with the champion if the best players can consistently outperform the average when the average is what the champion is balanced around?

let's take yasuo as an example.  Yasuo has average win rates or worse, but what makes him awful to play against?  His wind wall.  Even if he is consistently weaker than other champions, if luck is on the yasuo's side, he can significantly alter the course of a match with just the press of a button

to use a better example, let's say 70% of the users of a champion have 40% win rate and 30% have 70% win rate

if you average this, the average win rate is only 49% but guess what?  3 in 10 players are still going to KICK YOUR TEETH IN hands down...

I'm going to stop your quote war and tell you this.

Nobody gives a S***. The problem is that a large amount of people feel like damage is too high. It's not HIS JOB to fix that problem nor describe why. It's not his job to figure out why he and others feel that way. It's irrelevant. Regardless of whether or not it's dumb to feel that way, that feeling won't go away until something is changed. Therefore, SOMETHING has to change. It's Riot's job to figure out how to change it not him.

"feelings are not facts" yet the champions with winrates in the 40s have win rates up to the 80s on their best players

"feelings are not facts" yet yasuo has a 20% pick rate and 40% ban rate in diamond+

"feelings are not facts" yet akali pushed a 70% ban rate before her changes and the fact of the matter is that the only solution that they could agree on, they had to rewrite the base code of the game ONLY FOR AKALI to implement?

There's a big difference between telling a cook that the food is burnt, there is too much salt, or it is undercooked and telling them that they should be fired, the food is garbage (without specifying why), and that they're never coming back ever again (but they show up again next week). 

I personally don't think that riot needs to get "suggestions" from the boards, but they would help. I think that people need to make constructive posts that are detailed, not objectively toxic, and don't spread misinformation. 

I don't blame people for ignoring a forum that regularly upvotes posts that are like "Irelia just literally 1v5ed: game is trash now." with no clip that proves what happened.

actually, what if said cook is the only person who knows how to prepare food? (since riot is the only quality game in this genre and has the largest playerbase in the world consistently)

said cook starts to make horrible dishes while insisting that you eat them

what then?  do you starve?  are there any alternative food sources?

that's league's position right now.  Everyone loved it in the past and then they started making terrible decisions.  the playerbase doesn't want Tencent to drop it (which they will in a heartbeat the second its profits start going down...) because no other company will be able to afford the price of buying a game with $2 billion in annual profits and tencent would then shut it down

OR, if said company can afford it, they will be an even worse choice than tencent (EA, blizzard, maybe an oil company somewhere...)
but she did lel 1v5 its not a human capacity thing to do so it auto blows our minds.
Feelings aren't facts. So no, changes should not be made based on them at all

Real world example: I can feel that the brake pedal on my car is very slow to respond, much slower than other cars I've driven. It makes me worry about being able to stop in time if there were an accident in front of me. Do I need to get a force sensor, another car, and a closed track in order to provide facts of how much slower the peddle is to state my worry about it?

How customers feel about your product can be very important. It's the job of the person making the product to find out *why* those feelings exist.
Exactly my point.
facts aren't always facts either because they are skewed by perception, but rarely is a true fact disproven

When I say feelings, I don't mean. "I feel this champ/meta is too frustrating." Feelings was a poor word choice on my part. I essential meant we can tell something is wrong in this meta, which the current problem right now the damage and the easily accessible damage.

And as customers we **DO NOT** have to resort to instantly releasing our dissatisfaction immediately to the people working in the service. 

As a much more responsible and reasonable and borderline pleasurable customer to work with. You can step back from the frustrations. Analyze why something could be better and deliver a response.

If you worked in a service industry helping out customers. You would NOT want to work with someone calling a 'lazy fat fuck' for not 'fixing their product.' You'd just want to tell them to leave because no one asked you to stay around and buy whatever. 

But if you word out and illustrate your grief, they'll be more than willing to help. 

Obviously the boards isn't a place to receive what you ask for. But it's also not a place where you can rage post every 15 minutes because you're too immature to handle a defeat.

I also just want to add something from your OP

>The average player just knows when there is a problem, can feel when there is a problem

>can feel

> feel

This is the bigger issue with the boards. When you say you feel. You are automatically **NOT WRONG** because it is the way the individual feels. And if others feels the same way then it ultimately becomes a rally of people who *AREN'T WRONG*. Why? Because it's the way they feel. And you cannot argue against or invalidate feelings.

Therefore in order to promote discussion. It is a MUST to completely absolve your posts or arguments of feelings.

well, there are problems with that.  Service representatives get paid and taught to have appropriate responses

meanwhile, players complain when the people paid to do their job are doing the bare minimum and sometimes unsuccessfully

I agree with you, however, I should have stated my original post was not intended for those who simply just spat abusive words towards Riot, though I don't exactly hate them for it. I personally, never felt a community presence with Riot, when I played in 2012/2013 I never really went on the boards so I never had that experience. And I only played with one Rioter on Aram.

I do disagree with the instant feedback, I believe instant feedback (minus the abusive language) can RAISE awareness. Till the problem is pinpointed out. Like how quickly dark harvest got nerfed after its buff.

I prefer the old, strategy, team fight pace. Im not happy with the current but im not exactly uninstalling either

I think the food review scenario more often goes like this:
1. The food available wasn't what the particular customer wanted so they aren't happy
2. They changed the food available but the customer really liked the old food so they aren't happy
3. The food is actually pretty tasty and appeals to a variety of customers but this customer didn't like the brand of drink they got so they aren't happy

Or maybe we should stop comparing the two because while it fits as a loose analogy, comparing the over saltiness of chicken and the balancing act of a complex strategy game with over 140 characters isn't realistic.

The problem is that riot doesn't give players access to the necessary data to have any chance of making viable suggestions in how to resolve the problems with most of the game...

Opening up custom games to allow for a lot more manipulation by players to adjust numbers would probably see a lot of success in outsourcing the game's development, but riot doesn't do that. Imagine how many fun custom game modes could be created if players had the ability to control nearly any numerical aspect of the game, even if they couldn't directly add or suppress mechanics of the game.

Imagine how much fast the game could be balanced if you could just make unofficial nerfs and buffs to champions for you custom game mode or default block certain champions without bans... but instead they just leave players to complain about the single version of the game that they're allowed to have rather than letting the community dynamically adjust, or maybe even naturally fragment, along philosophical lines about the game design...
